key_issues: Here are the main legal issues:
Appropriateness of rejecting adjournment request due to perceived misrepresentation by counsel
Legal framework for handling adjournment requests in intellectual property disputes
Procedural propriety of imposing costs and depositing with PM Cares fund as a condition for pursuing appeal
Scope of powers of Intellectual Property Appellate Board in rectification petitions
Respect for constitutional right to legal representation and due process
Misrepresentation, fraud, and deception by counsel before the IPAB
Responsibility of counsel and clients for ensuring accuracy and truthfulness of representations
Power of courts and tribunals to penalize unprofessional or unethical behavior by advocates
Implications of reporting counsel's conduct to Bar Council
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary:**

**Case Details:**

*   Case No.: W.P.(C)-IPD 50/2021 & CM APPL. 7338/2021
*   Court: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
*   Date of Judgment: December 12, 2022
*   Judge: Hon'ble Mr. Justice C.Hari Shankar

**Background:**

This writ petition was filed under Article 226 of the Constitution of India to challenge an order dated 30th December 2020 passed by the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) in Rectification Petitions ORA/108/2020/TM/DEL and ORA/117/2020/TM/DEL. The petitioners were Respondent 1 before IPAB, and Respondent 2 was the appellant.

**Legal Issues:**

The legal issues in this case revolved around the dismissal of an adjournment application filed by Respondent 1 before IPAB. The learned IPAB had rejected the adjournment request and dismissed it with costs for alleged false representations made by Counsel Suwarn Rajan Chauhan (Enrollment No.D/667/2000) & Akshay Srivastava (Enrollment No.D/1967/2008).

**Arguments:**

Respondent 2's counsel argued that the adjournment application was dismissed unreasonably and in contravention of the principles of natural justice. They also claimed that Counsel Suwarn Rajan Chauhan & Akshay Srivastava's representations were genuine.

In contrast, the petitioner's counsel contended that the allegations levelled against them and their failure to attend IPAB hearings on December 29th, 2020.

**Court Findings:**

The court found that Counsel Suwarn Rajan Chauhan & Akshay Srivastava have not shown any legitimate reason for not attending the hearing on 30th December. The fact also showed that they had made misleading statements before IPAB.

Moreover, the decision of taking action against them to Bar Council of India was seen to be correct as per the court.

**Decision:**

The Court held that the learned IPAB's order dismissing the adjournment application with costs was sustainable in law. The decision of referring the matter to the Bar Council was also upheld by the court.

Court orders for costs of Rs.5,000/- to Counsel Suwarn Rajan Chauhan and Akshay Srivastava be paid via a PM Cares fund deposit slip by January 7th, 2021. If not complied with, their names would be reported to Bar Council India

printouts. It is a matter of regret that such irresponsible false 
representations are made before this Board. This sought of 
misrepresentations are unwarranted and does not go well with the bar 
and bench, we may be constrained to report this sought of reckless 
submissions to the Bar Council. Since a deliberate wrong irresponsible 
representation has been before us with an intent to secure an 
adjournment in the matter the said Adjournment application is being 
dismissed with costs of Rs.5,000/ -. The same may be deposited with 
PM Cares fund at the earliest not before 07th January 2021 and the 
deposit slip be filed with this Board failing which we shall report to 
Bar Council of India to take appropriate action against the said 
counsels Suwarn Rajan Chauhan (Enrollment No.D/667/2000) & 
Akshay Srivastava (Enrollment No.D/1967/2008).” 
 
4. 
The learned IPAB proceeded to pass directions against learned 
Counsel for having, as it thought, made false averments before it with 
respect to availability of learned Counsel.  It has also awarded costs and 
has referred the matter to the Bar Council of India in the event of failure

to pay the costs imposed. 
 
5. 
In the present petition, this Court, vide order dated 23rd February 
2021, directed the learned Counsel who had been appearing in the matter 
before the learned IPAB to file individual affidavits, explaining their 
failure to be present before the learned IPAB on 30th December 2020. 
 
6. 
Three learned Counsel were appearing on behalf of Respondent 1 
before the learned IPAB, namely Abhilash Gupta, Akshay Srivastava and 
Suwarn Rajan Chauhan. As is apparent from para 3 of the impugned 
order, the learned IPAB proceeded on the premise that Akshay Srivastava 
was the lead Counsel. Save and except a statement to the said effect 
having been made by learned Counsel for Respondent 2, there appears to 
be no justification for the learned IPAB’s presumption that Akshay 
Srivastava was the lead Counsel in the matter. 
 
7. 
Before this Court, it has been submitted that the arguing Counsel 
before the learned IPAB was Suwarn Rajan Chauhan who was indeed 
under quarantine and expired on 30th April 2021. 
 
8. 
This Court has also seen some of the earlier orders passed by the 
learned IPAB in the said proceedings in which it does appear that Suwarn 
Rajan Chauhan was principally appearing on behalf of the petitioner. 
 
9. 
In that view of the matter, this Court is unable to sustain the 
impugned order, insofar as it refused to adjourn the matter on the premise 
that Akshay Srivastava was the lead Counsel and that he was at Chennai 
on the date when the matter was taken up. 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:13.12.2022
15:36:20
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
Neutral Citation Number :2022/DHC/005508 
CS(COMM) 310/2020                                                                                               Page 4 of 6 
 
 
10. 
Even otherwise, in my considered opinion, before taking an 
adverse view against the Counsel on the basis of a Facebook post, and 
referring the matter to the Bar Council of India, the learned IPAB ought, 
at the very least, to have given an opportunity to the Counsel to explain 
the circumstances. Postings on Facebook cannot be treated as 
determinative of the location of a person at a particular point of time, at 
least by a Court. Even if a Court is to take an adverse view in that regard, 
the Counsel ought to be given an opportunity to explain the position 
before such a view is taken. This Court is of the concerned opinion that 
the learned IPAB was needlessly strict in imposing costs and referring 
the matter to the Bar Council of India in such circumstances. 
 
11. 
In view of the fact that Suwarn Rajan Chauhan was indeed 
quarantined at the relevant time and expired, unfortunately, thereafter, 
this Court is not entering into any of the other aspects of the matter 
regarding non-absence of Counsel on behalf of the petitioner on 30th 
December 2020. 
 
12. 
So far as the earlier adjournments taken by the petitioner, if any, 
are concerned, the matter stands covered by the following passage from 
the judgment of the Supreme Court in State Bank of India v. Chandra 
Govind Ji1: 
 
“7. 
In ascertaining whether a party had reasonable 
opportunity to put forward his case or not, one should not 
ordinarily go beyond the date on which adjournment is 
sought for. The earlier adjournment, if any, granted would 
certainly be for reasonable grounds and that aspect need not 
                                          
1 (2000) 8 SCC 532 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:13.12.2022
15:36:20
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number :2022/DHC/005508 
CS(COMM) 310/2020                                                                                               Page 5 of 6 
 
be once again examined if on the date on which adjournment 
is sought for the party concerned has a reasonable ground. 
The mere fact that in the past adjournments had been sought 
for would not be of any materiality. If the adjournment had 
been sought for on flimsy grounds the same would have been 
rejected. Therefore, in our view, the High Court as well as the 
learned District Judge and the Rent Controller have all 
missed the essence of the matter.” 
 
13. 
In view of the aforesaid discussion, the impugned order dated 30th 
December 2020 is quashed and set aside. The rectification petitions filed 
by Respondent 2 shall stand restored for re-hearing.  
 
14. 
Inasmuch as the learned IPAB has subsequently been abolished, 
the rectification petitions would have to be heard by this Court. The 
Registry is directed to register the rectification petitions under the 
appropriate nomenclature and list them before the Court on 23rd February 
2023 for hearing and disposal. Let the record from the learned IPAB be 
also requisitioned prior to the said date. 
 
15. 
For the purpose of registration, the Respondent 2 is directed to 
place on record a photocopy of the entire record along with an 
appropriate affidavit under Section 65-B of the Evidence Act, 1872. 
Respondent 2 undertakes to provide the registry with the entire record of 
the rectification petitions filed before the learned IPAB within a period of 
four weeks. On the said record being provided the rectification petitions 
would be numbered and registered before this Court and listed before the 
Court for disposal on 23rd February 2023. 
 
16. 
Mr. Siddharth Bamba learned Counsel for Respondent 2 points out 
that, Respondent 2 was enjoying interim relief vide order dated 10th July 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:13.12.2022
15:36:20
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
Neutral Citation Number :2022/DHC/005508 
CS(COMM) 310/2020                                                                                               Page 6 of 6 
 
2020 passed by the learned IPAB which was in force till the passing of 
the impugned order dated 30th December 2020. 
 
17. 
As the impugned order, which is in favour of Respondent 2, has 
been quashed only on the ground of violation of the principles of natural 
justice, Respondent 2 would be entitled to be restored to the position in 
which it was at the time of its passing. 
 
18. 
As such, the order dated 10th July 2020 passed by the learned 
IPAB shall stand restored and remain in operation till this Court decides 
the two rectification petitions. 
 
19. 
List the rectification petitions, duly registered, for hearing and 
disposal on 23rd February 2023. 
 
20. 
This writ petition stands allowed accordingly.  No costs. 
 
 
 
C.HARI SHANKAR, J

nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 2 from the PDF: "48. Vinod Kumar v. Intellectual Property Appellate Board & Ors.pdf"

On December 30, 2020, the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) passed an order dismissing an adjournment application filed by Respondent No.1 with costs of Rs.5,000/-. The IPAB found that the counsel representing Respondent No.1 had falsely represented that he was in self-quarantine due to COVID-19 when in fact he was on a holiday.

The IPAB noted that the counsels' office was closed due to COVID-19 and employees were isolated at home, but screen shots from Facebook showed that the main counsel, Akshay Srivastava, had been traveling for a holiday since December 24, 2020. The IPAB criticized the irresponsible false representation and warned of reporting it to the Bar Council if costs were not deposited within a specified timeframe.

Key facts:

* Date: December 30, 2020
* Amount: Rs.5,000/- (costs)
* Parties: Respondent No.1, Suwarn Rajan Chauhan, Akshay Srivastava

tree_structure.summary:
Here is a summary of the provided document section from Vinod Kumar v. Intellectual Property Appellate Board & Ors (2022/DHC/005508 CS(COMM) 310/2020), focusing on legal proceedings, facts, arguments, decisions, parties, dates, and amounts:

**Background and Facts:**

The Delhi High Court at New Delhi heard a petition by Vinod Kumar against the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB). The case concerned costs imposed after an adjournment was refused by IPAB.

**Key Parties:**

* Petitioner: Vinod Kumar
* Respondents:
	+ Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB)
	+ Other respondents not specified

**Key Dates:**

* 23rd February 2021: High Court directed individual affidavits to be filed explaining the failure to appear before IPAB on 30th December 2020.
* 30th December 2020: Alleged non-appearance of counsel for Respondent 1 before IPAB.
* 30th April 2021: Death of Suwarn Rajan Chauhan, who was allegedly under quarantine.

**Court Decision:**

The High Court did not sustain the impugned order by IPAB that refused to adjourn the matter on the premise that Akshay Srivastava was the lead Counsel and he was at Chennai when the matter was taken up. The decision was influenced by evidence showing Suwarn Rajan Chauhan was mainly appearing for Vinod Kumar.

**Significance:**

The decision implies that costs imposed after an adjournment was refused may be revisable or could have been avoided depending on circumstances, such as the death of a key counsel.

Source: Vinod Kumar v. Intellectual Property Appellate Board & Ors (2022/DHC/005508 CS(COMM) 310/2020).

**Document:** Vinod Kumar v. Intellectual Property Appellate Board & Ors.pdf (48)

The judgment was delivered by the High Court of Delhi in the matter of CS(COMM) 310/2020.

**Facts and Parties:**

* The petitioner, Vinod Kumar, challenged an order passed by the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB).
* Respondent 1 is IPAB, while Respondent 2 is the Registrar of Geographical Indications of India.
* The dispute relates to a rectification petition filed before the IPAB.

**Legal Proceedings:**

* The matter was listed in WP(C)-IPD 50/2021 and CM APPL. 7338/2021.
* An order dated December 30, 2020, was challenged by the petitioner.

**Arguments and Decisions:**

* The Court held that IPAB was needlessly strict in imposing costs and referring the matter to the Bar Council of India after a counsel's Facebook post.
* The court noted that postings on social media cannot be determinative of someone's location at a particular point in time, without an opportunity for explanation.
* The impugned order dated December 30, 2020, was quashed and set aside.
* The rectification petitions filed by Respondent 2 stand restored for re-hearing.

**Dates and Amounts:**

* None mentioned

**Judgment:**

The Court's judgment was delivered on [not specified] in the matter of CS(COMM) 310/2020.

Here is a summary of page 4 from the provided PDF (Vinod Kumar v. Intellectual Property Appellate Board & Ors.pdf):

**Decisions and Rulings**

* The Court finds that the IPAB acted needlessly strict in imposing costs and referring the matter to the Bar Council of India.
* Counsel should be given an opportunity to explain their position before adverse views are taken based on social media posts.

**Judgment**

* Suwarn Rajan Chauhan, who was supposed to appear as Counsel, was indeed quarantined at the relevant time and unfortunately passed away afterwards.
* The Court chooses not to consider the absence of Counsel on December 30, 2020.

**Legal Precedent**

* The decision to not grant earlier adjournments is covered by a Supreme Court judgment (State Bank of India v. Chandra Govind Ji), which states that one should not ordinarily go beyond the date on which an adjournment is sought.

Even otherwise, in my considered opinion, before taking an 
adverse view against the Counsel on the basis of a Facebook post, and 
referring the matter to the Bar Council of India, the learned IPAB ought, 
at the very least, to have given an opportunity to the Counsel to explain 
the circumstances. Postings on Facebook cannot be treated as 
determinative of the location of a person at a particular point of time, at 
least by a Court. Even if a Court is to take an adverse view in that regard, 
the Counsel ought to be given an opportunity to explain the position 
before such a view is taken. This Court is of the concerned opinion that 
the learned IPAB was needlessly strict in imposing costs and referring 
the matter to the Bar Council of India in such circumstances. 
 
11. 
In view of the fact that Suwarn Rajan Chauhan was indeed 
quarantined at the relevant time and expired, unfortunately, thereafter, 
this Court is not entering into any of the other aspects of the matter 
regarding non-absence of Counsel on behalf of the petitioner on 30th 
December 2020.

are concerned, the matter stands covered by the following passage from 
the judgment of the Supreme Court in State Bank of India v. Chandra

nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 5 from the PDF document:

The Delhi High Court sets aside the impugned order dated December 30, 2020, which dismissed rectification petitions filed by Respondent 2 (appellant). The court directs that these petitions be reheard and restored for further consideration.

In considering whether to grant adjournments, the court emphasizes that the focus should be on determining if a party has reasonable grounds for seeking an adjournment. Past instances of seeking adjournments are not determinative, but rather the specific circumstances of each case. 

The court's decision is as follows:

* The impugned order dated 30th December 2020 is quashed and set aside.
* The rectification petitions filed by Respondent 2 shall be re-heard before the High Court.

Here is a summary of page 6 from the PDF document "48. Vinod Kumar v. Intellectual Property Appellate Board & Ors.pdf":

**Legal Facts and Proceedings:**

* The Court is considering the writ petition (W.P.(C)-IPD 50/2021) filed by Vinod Kumar against the IPAB and others.
* A previous order dated July 10, 2020 was passed by the learned IPAB, which has been quashed due to a violation of natural justice principles.

**Court's Decision:**

* The Court quashes the impugned order dated December 30, 2020 in favor of Respondent 2.
* Respondent 2 is restored to its position at the time of passing of the July 10, 2020 order.
* The July 10, 2020 order is restored and remains in operation till the Court decides on two rectification petitions.

**Court's Orders:**

* List the rectification petitions for hearing and disposal on February 23, 2023.
* The writ petition is allowed, with no costs ordered.
